cards.english: consonants g, h and k g (g) Guka gucia guoko gwaikwa - Grandfather, pull my hand Gĩra gĩkombe gĩkĩ - Come for this cup Gĩkombe h (h) Haha hena heho - This place is cold Huha mwaki wahota - Blow the fire if you can Hoho no ya hoha - the capsicum has shriveled k (k) Kaĩrĩtu kena karamu - the girl has a pen Karamu Kahĩĩ nĩ karatha kanyoni - The boy has shot the bird Kana kona kora kora - The child saw a frog and ran away Kiura - frog Kora - small frog
cards.cultural_notes: Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons by Emmanuel Kariuki. Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons

cards.english: week 4 - 4 11. Ĩkũmi na ĩmwe - eleven 12. Ĩkũmi na ĩgĩrĩ - twelve 13. Ĩkũmi na ĩthatũ - thirteen We take a break from this progression and move on to number twenty. The archaic term for ten is "Mũrongo." It is used from number twenty onwards. 20. Mĩrongo ĩrĩĩ (literally two tens). 21. Mĩrongo ĩrĩĩ na ĩmwe, 22. Mĩrongo ĩrĩĩ na ĩgĩrĩĩ This goes on to 30. Mĩrongo ĩtatũ until we get to 99. Mĩrongo kenda na kenda The following are three digit numbers starting with 100. 100. Igana rĩmwe, 101. Igana rĩmwe na ĩmwe, 102. Igana rĩmwe na ĩgĩrĩĩ 120. Igana rĩmwe rĩa mĩrongo ĩrĩĩ - one hundred and twenty 141. Igana rĩmwe rĩa mĩrongo ĩna na ĩmwe. 199. Igana rĩmwe rĩa mĩrongo kenda na kenda. 1000. Ngiri ĩmwe - one thousand. For 'one million' we use a term borrowed from English - million 1000000. Mirioni ĩmwe - One million
cards.cultural_notes: Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons by Emmanuel Kariuki. Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons

cards.english: t, th, ny t (t) tene O Na Tene na tene - forever and ever Tinia taama maita matano - cut the fabric five times Tara mbeca - count the money, tooria - accomplish, teta akũhe irio - complain so he/she gives you food, tunga karwĩmbo - compose a song th (th) thaani Thaani ĩno nĩ theru - this plate is clean Thooma ũtarĩ na itherũ - read without joking Thenga haha (ehera haha) - move away from here, thutha wa nyumba - behind the house, thooma ibuku rĩaku - read your book ny (ny) Nyanya Ruga Nyanya na nyeni - cook tomatoes and greens Mũrarũ nĩ Nyoka - Mũrarũ is a snake Nyamũ cia gĩthaka - wild animals, nyeni nĩ njega - vegetables are good, Nyenje ĩ gĩko - a cockroach is dirty
cards.cultural_notes: Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons by Emmanuel Kariuki. Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons

cards.kikuyu: This image is an excellent guide for learning some key aspects of Kikuyu pronunciation. ## Kikuyu Pronunciation Guide The word at the top, **Nĩtwĩrĩririkanie**, means **"Let us remember"** (literally: "remind ourselves"). The guide then provides phonetic examples for the key vowels and a couple of consonants: ### Vowels Kikuyu has seven cardinal vowels, some of which are marked with a tilde (~), a diaeresis (¨), or an acute accent (´) in other texts to show the two different degrees of openness for the same sound. This guide uses the tilde to distinguish them.

cards.english: This is a **bilabial fricative**. It's not the hard English 'B'. Instead, it's a soft sound made by bringing both lips close together and forcing the air through, often sounding like a **soft 'V'** or sometimes like 'W'.
cards.cultural_notes: Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons by Emmanuel Kariuki. Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons

cards.english: Note: The English example for **B** (**mahaBharat**) is pointing out the softer, aspirated /bh/ sound found in some Indic languages, which is closer to the softer Kikuyu sound than the hard English 'B'.
cards.kikuyu: Pronounced as the **'ch'** in **ch**air or the **'sh'** in **sh**oe, but often somewhere in between. It is usually represented as **/ʃ/** or **/tʃ/**.
cards.cultural_notes: Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons by Emmanuel Kariuki. Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons

cards.kikuyu: The image provides a vocabulary list for the major organs of the human **digestive system** in Kikuyu. The title, **Ciĩga cia njĩra ya irio**, translates to: * **Ciĩga** means **parts** or **organs**. * **cia** means **of the**. * **njĩra** means **way** or **path**. * **ya** means **of**. * **irio** means **food**. * So, **Ciĩga cia njĩra ya irio** literally means **"The parts of the path of food"** or **"The digestive system."** --- ## Kikuyu Digestive System Vocabulary Here are the Kikuyu terms for the organs labeled in the diagram:

cards.kikuyu: The image provides a list of Kikuyu words that are phonetically similar but have different meanings (homophones or minimal pairs), illustrating the importance of correct pronunciation and tones. The heading **"Thooma ciugo ici—read these words aloud na ũtunge ũhoro—and compose sentences"** encourages practice. --- ### Group 1: Words with Different Tone/Length/Prefix
